snippet.textDisplay: As a retired infection prevention nurse I'd like to add these comments and ask a few questions for my own knowledge. All good and well with this video and there are some excellent suggestions.  But, I am watching human hands touch the outside of a cardboard box which is presumably contaminated, then grab the inside bag. Theoretically, that would contaminate that bag as well. Same thing with emptying the take out food containers as I saw the outsides of those touch the plate. In the outside world, nothing can be considered sterile. The best we can hope for is as clean as possible. May I suggest using cooking tongs to remove those cereal bags or other inner container bags from the external cardboard packaging or to remove food from the potentially contaminated cardboard or paper wrappers? Condiment packages could easily be wiped down with a disinfectant cloth before opening as could cans, bottles or other packages. My questions are these. 1. My husband and I are both in our early 70's, mid 60's, respectively. We have no close by family to shop for us. (The closest one is 3 hrs away and is an ICU RN in a growing hot spot city) That necessitates us doing for ourselves. Until I saw this video, even with my background in IP, we shopped before the pandemic and at the onset of the pandemic, and we have had to go out during, to get necessities. Now, my pantry and fridge contain items that may potentially be contaminated. Everything that I've brought into the house might be potentially contaminated. Do I remove everything, disinfect and return it to the storage areas, or would it be more feasible to disinfect the items as we need it, before using it? I usually wipe down all cans with soap and water before opening them and wash all fruits and veggies before preparing them, just because...  At this point, I am ready to spray down my entire pantry with 10:1 water/bleach solution or with lysol. 2  PPE...do we need to consider wearing PPE...mask and gloves when out in public especially with our ages? The CDC has put out several advisories regarding their usage by the general public. Don't wear them...not needed, wear them...you might need that protection from an asymptomatic COVID 19 carrier.  Simple face masks (surgical masks) are not designed to intercept viruses. The best they can do is prevent an already sick person from blowing them out all over the general public. We have a VERY few N95 masks on hand...maybe 2 a piece that I used for crafting purposes. They are sufficient to prevent us from inhaling the COVID 19 virus. But, as we all know, if those masks become wet with sweat, saliva or oils from our face or makeup, they render them useless. What do you advise?

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you, Dr Jeff!!!  I don't mean to be give stress, but as constructive criticism and perhaps for any followup video, addressing cross or continued contamination would be an extra layer of precaution.  For example, before you washed your hands, the water was turned on with a possibly contaminated hand ... hands were properly washed ... but then, a clean hand turned the tap off, which was originally touched by potentially a contaminated hand.  Any new video that you can share with this in mind would be gratefully appreciated in the best interest keeping your viewers healthy with that extra layer of precaution.  Cheers!

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you! This is the best advice I have seen in a while. If you don't have disinfectant, consider this..Bleach
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends a diluted bleach solution (⅓ cup bleach per 1 gallon of water or 4 teaspoons bleach per 1 quart of water) for virus disinfection. Wear gloves while using bleach, and never mix it with ammonia—or anything, in fact—except water. (The only exception is when doing laundry with detergent.) Once mixed, don’t keep the solution for longer than a day because the bleach will lose potency and can degrade certain plastic containers.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dear Dr.Jeffrey, I've watched your video, and I thank you. I personally live in Italy and use a similar attitude towards groceries, but I have a few comments:


1. you do not use gloves during disinfection, and clean your hands continually: but what if you had some scratches on your fingers? Wouldn't it be better to use gloves AND disinfect them from time to time (which is easier because gloves have a smoother surface)?
2. you use common detergent/disinfectants, whereas we know from here
https://www.journalofhospitalinfection.com/article/S0195-6701(20)30046-3/fulltext
that you need minimum 0,1% hypochlorite solution (or ethanol alcohol 62%+, mixed with water);
3. you're bringing your parents broccoli without prior disinfecting them (you only treated plastic);
4. you might want to briefly submerge fruits in hypochlorite solution for a couple of minutes, then rinse and dry them: probably cleaning each piece is overkill: don't you agree?;
5. you're worried about where people might have TOUCHED fomites (objects): I'm as much concerned about where people could have BREATHED on them, like on nutritional information, to read them better;
6. the "dirty" and "safe" zones of your table are too close: accidental contamination is highly possible: I'd rather use two separate tables, or a "dirty" table and a "safe" kitchen shelf;
7. you might have disinfected the sauces plastic sachets, before opening.



Please, bear with my suggestions: I'm not into criticizing at all, what you are doing is great, and few people even talk about these things!
And it's a great idea, using microwawe for sandwiches. Pizza, too, can be put for a minute or two in a traditional oven at 200+ C° as soon as it reaches home.


Thanks again!
Thank you!! I've shared with everyone I know.  please stay safe

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you for everything you're doing. You all are heroes in the truest sense of the word.



I am a little bit curious about how significant a threat contracting COVID-19 is from groceries. I grant that wiping everything down is better than not, but it seems to me that the primary mode of infection has been inhalation of respiratory droplets. The CDC even says:

"Coronaviruses are generally thought to be spread from person-to-person through respiratory droplets. Currently there is no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food. Before preparing or eating food it is important to always wash your hands with soap and water for 20 seconds for general food safety. Throughout the day wash your hands after blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing, or going to the bathroom.

It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads."

So while this is definitely a useful video, we should be prioritizing keeping away from people and social distancing as the top priority. If you have a mask, use it. Reuse it. Sanitize it in an oven at 160 degrees for 30 minutes. https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/3QYVWO4kj5qwuSHnhcM9uQ . DO NOT HORDE THEM AND THROW THEM AWAY EVERY DAY. CDC says "extended use alone is unlikely to diminish a masks protection". Medical personnel should take top priority and should not be forced to reuse masks. For the everyday public, tho keeping 2 or 3 masks to reuse if they work in an essential job or need to go to the grocery store, I think, is the most reasonable approach.

https://www.quora.com/profile/Thomas-Talhelm These posts cite many studies on the effectiveness of masks, even makeshift ones will block over half of viral particles. And in the real world, a surgical mask is just as effective as an N95 in a hospital environment. Mask use gives roughly a 75% reduction in transmission rates of respiratory viruses in a care-at-home environment.

snippet.textDisplay:
Many good points, but I think it's a bit much to expect the average person to do. I've been a clean freak for most of my life, but I still put all my groceries right on the counter, then when I'm done, I wash down the counters. Spares me all the hassle of being careful of each item, when I know that whole section of counter is dirty.

I don't wash each item, either. I put them in the pantry, where they sit for several days prior to anyone using them, thus allowing time for the virus to die off on hard surfaces.

I didn't know it was living 2 years in the freezer, so I'll bear that in mind going forward, but as to the rest, I think it's a bit of overkill. My spouse has covid19, and I've been living with him for 4 weeks, since we were both exposed on a plane (presumably), and he came down with a fever 2+ weeks ago. I still don't have it, due to relentless washing and sterilizing, as well as taping off the door knobs on the fridge, microwave, and stove.


I have the long handles on the fridge and microwave, so I sterilize everything, tape the handles at the halfway point, and he uses the top half (he's taller than me), and I use the bottom half, so we never touch the same area. I have one side of the kitchen, he has the other, and the stove has one burner reserved for me, and one for him, so we don't touch the same knobs.


We each have separate towels, and each have one faucet handle to use at the kitchen sink. (takes forever for the hot to get there, so both are basically cold water faucets). I put all the dishes he needs right out on his counter, so he doesn't need to get into the cupboards for dishes or silverware, and then he doesn't contaminate anything but his side of the stove and counters. I still treat everything as if it's contaminated, just to be sure, and it's worked so far. 4+ weeks of living with someone exposed/infected right here, and I still don't have it.


I still treat everything in the house as if it just rolled over a dog pooh, and that's a lot more effective than thinking of it as glitter. If I grabbed a can of beans, and it had just rolled over a dog pooh, I'd be a lot more inclined to be careful than if it had some glitter on it. Same with door knobs, light switches, etc. Dog pooh is a great incentivizer to wash, and not touch. Now, if I could just get him to stop touching everything, that would be helpful. : )

snippet.textDisplay:
- the 3 day advice is great. I tell relatives the same. same with things they order, or get delivered.

- thankfully I live in a full house so I just open my car trunk with gloves, put everything in front of my door and take off gloves
- then I sanitize the car with windex/glass cleaner and microfiber towel (works great, trust me). everything I touch has to be wiped down. I try to think what I do when I get in and out of the car. no spot, handle, belt can remain infected. back door button? clean it. everything gets clean. then I keep the car doors open until I finish with cleaning groceries. clean air is nice, so they said.
- I use lightly diluted sanitizer in a container. not sure if you can get that in the US but it's common stuff in EU. basically just sanitizer in a 1L-2L bottle in a thick form. you put that into water and you have a large amount of sanitizer. all you need besides that is an old t-shirt / rag. If I can soak something in the diluted solution, I just drown that thing. If I can only wipe it off (cardboard), I do that. And I just let them air dry / sit wet, cause every sanitizer needs time to work - supposedly.
- then I wash my hands. go back again, clean every door handle outside. the gate, the gate's frame, everything I usually or ever touched.
- then I clean every door handle and maybe switch inside as well, and also clean the handles on faucets. the coffee machine, handles in the kitchen, everything. think how many things you or the people you live with touch. I went back to live with my elderly to support them, do the shopping and stuff. and I know they are really hard to adapt. ie.: someone can go out, try their best to keep every rule BUT THEN they take out their phone outside, return home, and start using it after washing hands and assume its clean. it's all over at this point.
- clean electronics. phones, laptops, keyboards. again, glass cleaner works great, it evaporates. of course don't drown your phone in it, but be generous, make sure to hit every spot. if you have a case, well, be thorough. you can even remove case. IF you find this all too hard, you can just use a zip-loc bag and wrap your phone up before you go out. it works great. you can just spray the whole bag down or wipe it all off when you get home, take out phone, easy. clean phone.
- lately I started using a hairdryer to warm up letters and money. it can easily reach 60C which is said to work against COVID-19. of course, be careful not to touch said item, or wash your hands, the hair dryer... think is very thoroughly.

I realize the whole process is very cumbersome, but you don't need to shop every single day. If you must use your car each day, well, use gloves and/or hand sanitizer. Remember, if your hands are dirty, hand sanitizer will NOT cut it!

Stay safe everyone!
The cures, the help is on the way, but you have to hang in there. If you catch it now, you might not make it back alive.
If you hang in there for a few months... you might as well just save your life.
